AllReferenceableTypeInstructions.description:
Supplementary generation instructions for all types. In this variant
there may be references to exact values instead of the exact values
themselves.

AvailableDatabaseDescription.description: Describes a database that could possibly be used.

BlockLanguageDescription.description:
Augments a language with information about the UI layer. This definition is
used by the editors, especially the block editor, to show customized editors
for different languages. These customizations include:

* The blocks that are shown in the sidebar.
* Possibly language specific sidebars.
* Definitions of the actual blocks.
* Possibly language specific editor components.

blockLanguageGeneratorId.description:
The ID of the block language that may have been used to generate this
block language.

createdAt.description: Date & time this resource was created

defaultProgrammingLanguageId.description: The programming language this block language uses by default.

editorBlocks.description: How blocks should be represented in the drag & drop editor.

editorComponents.description:
Specialised components that should be shown for this block
language.

grammarId.description: The grammar that this block language may visualize.

id.description: The internal ID of this language model.

localGeneratorInstructions.description: Information on how to (re)-generate this block language.

name.description: The name that should be displayed to the user.

rootCssClasses.description: CSS classes that should be applied at the root

sidebars.description: How the available blocks should be represented in the sidebar.

slug.description:
A unique (but possibly empty) id. If this is undefined the language has
no builtin counterpart on the client.

updatedAt.description: Date & time this resource was updated the last time

BlockLanguageGeneratorDocument.description: All possible instructions to generate a block language.

ChildCardinalityDescription.description: Describes how often a certain type may appear in a sequence.

CodeResourceSettingsComponentDescription.description: Displays the settings for a certain resource

ConstantBlocksSidebarCategoryDescription.description: A category that is defined statically

ConstantSidebarBlockDescription.description: A block that is given statically

defaultNode.description:
This description will be instanciated every time an "empty" node
is needed. This happens e.g. when the user starts dragging this
block from the sidebar.

displayName.description: The name to be displayed in the sidebar

DropDebugComponentDescription.description: Displays debug information about an ongoing drag process

EditorBlockDescription.description:
Describes how certain nodes in the syntaxtree should be presented
to an end user inside the drag & drop interface.

describedType.description: Nodes of this type are presented using this block.

EditorComponentDescription.description: Any component that could be displayed in the actual editor view.

EnumRestrictionDescription.description: Restricts a string to be one of a given set of values

FixedBlocksSidebarCategoryDescription.description: Defines which blocks to show in a certain category.

FixedBlocksSidebarDescription.description:
Defines the overall look of a sidebar. It at least sorts available blocks
into categories.

caption.description: The name that should be displayed to the user.

categories.description: The actual blocks are categorized into categories.

GeneratedBlocksSidebarCategoryDescriptio.description:
A category that uses only generated blocks. This allows for a syntax
that is a little more compact.

GeneratedBlocksSidebarDescription.description:
A sidebar description that may use partly generated blocks and partly
constant categories.

GeneratedSidebarBlockDescription.description: A block that has its block generated.

GrammarDescription.description: A whole grammar with all user-facing documentation.

InternalTypeInstructionsDescription_Refe.description:
Instructions on how to generate a single block for a type. This type
is not intended to be used directly, please use `TypeInstructionsDescription`
or `ReferenceableTypeInstructionsDescription` instead.

JsonAstComponentDescription.description: Displays a readonly JSON version of the AST

LengthRestrictionDescription.description: Restricts the maximum length of things.

ManualBlockLanguageGeneratorDescription.description:
A very manual approach to block language generation. Uses specific type
instructions and traits to

MaximumLengthRestrictionDescription.description: Restricts the maximum length of things.

MinimumLengthRestrictionDescription.description: Restricts the minimum length of things.

MixedBlocksSidebarCategoryDescription.description:
A category description that may use partly generated blocks and
partly constant blocks.

NodeAttributeDescription.description:
Attributes of a node are either validation atoms like properties
or children or visual cues like terminals or rows.

NodeChildrenGroupDescription.description: All children group types that are available

NodeConcreteTypeDescription.description:
This is the basic description to introduce a new type for
any kind of node. If you are familiar with schema languages
like XML-Schema, JSON-Schema, NG-Relax, ... this will be
(hopefully) nothing too surprising for you.

This schema language is modeled losely after XML-Schema,
but enhanced with various UI-related features.

The restriction system for simple properties is modelled after
facets in XML-Schema: https://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-2/#defn-coss

Builtin types are:
- String
- Integer
- Boolean

The restriction system for child nodes is also modelled losely
after XML schemas complex element types. An important deviation
is that child nodes can be distribibuted in multiple groups. This
means that a single node can be parent to two unrelated sub-trees.
XML schema in contrast allows exactly nodes and attributes as
sub-trees.

The actual attributes of this node (properties or children) are stored
as a list because the order does matter during string serialization
or automatic UI generation. And whilst syntactic terminal symbols are
not actually required at all when validating a tree, they are meaningful
for the automation process.

Over time the grammar structure has deviated from being "validation
only", it now also contains visual information about the row layout of
the text based representation.

language.description:
This is effectively a namespace, allowing identical
names for nodes in different languages.

name.description:
The name of this not, this is used to lookup the name of a
corresponding type.

NodeDescription.description:
This description regulates how all ASTs should be stored when
written to disk or sent over the wire. It requires every
node to at least tell its name and some hint how a node can be
constructed at runtime.

The data of a node is split up in two broader categories:
Children, which may be nested and properties, which should
not allow any nesting.

children.description:
Nodes may have children in various categories. This base class
makes no assumptions about the names of children. Examples for
children in multiple categories would be things like "attributes"
and generic "children" in a specialization for XML.

language.description:
This is effectively a namespace, allowing identical
names for nodes in different languages.

name.description:
The name of this not, this is used to lookup the name of a
corresponding type.

properties.description:
Nodes may have all kinds of properties that are specific to their
concrete use.

NodeIntegerTypeRestrictions.description: The restrictions that are applicable to integers

NodeLocation.description:
Contains the path to find a certain node in a syntax tree.
These paths currently always start from the root node.

NodeLocationStep.description:
Determines the category and the index in that category
of a node.

NodeOneOfTypeDescription.description:
Creates a possibility to define multiple NodeTypes as alternatives
to each other *without* introducing an artificial node type. This
is helpful for e.g. the root node or when using recursive definitions.

NodePropertyIntegerDescription.description: Describes the "Integer" type and describes how it can be restricted.

NodePropertyStringDescription.description: Denotes the "string" type and describes ways it can be further restricted.

NodePropertyTypeDescription.description: Properties are used for atomic values and may be optional.

NodeStringTypeRestrictions.description: The restrictions that are applicable to strings

NodeTailoredDescription.description:
A description of a node that has "holes" in it, which may be filled
with the help of an existing AST. Often used to fill in some data at
the beginning of a started drag.

NodeTerminalSymbolDescription.description: A terminal symbol that would be expected.

NodeTypeDescription.description:
Types may either be concrete new type or an alias
grouping together multiple other types.

NodeTypesAllowedDescription.description:
Every immediate child must be part of this list of allowed types. The order
in which these children appear in is not relevant.

NodeTypesChildReference.description:
A simple type reference is a shortcut for an element with
minOccurs = 1 and maxOccurs = 1;

NodeTypesChoiceDescription.description:
Tries the given operators in the order they appear in. If any of them is
satisfied, the child group is considered valid.

NodeTypesParenthesesDescription.description:
Allows to group different children together and to
apply a cardinality to them. Mixing different child group semantics is explicitly
forbidden, each group may be either nothing but "allowed" or nothing but "sequence"
combinators.

NodeTypesSequenceDescription.description:
In a sequence every child must occur in exact the order and cardinality
that is specified by this description.

NodeVisualContainerDescription.description: Groups together various nodes in a certain kind of layout.

OccursSpecificDescription.description: A verbos definition of minimum and maximum occurences.

ProjectDescription.description:
The "shallow" properties of a project that do not contain any
complicated standalone resources.

ProjectName.description:
The name of the project. May only contain more or less friendly
characters.

ProjectSlug.description:
The url-friendly name of the project. May only contain characters that do not
mean any trouble in URLs.

ProjectSourceDescription.description:
Some projects are based on external sources, especially regarding
the data in the databases. These references may be used to
correctly acknowledge such sources.

createdAt.description: Date & time this resource was created

updatedAt.description: Date & time this resource was updated the last time

ProjectUsesBlockLanguageDescription.description: A block language that is used by this project.

QualifiedTypeName.description: Used when refererring to types that are defined other languages.

ReferenceableTypeInstructionsDescription.description: Type instructions that may contain references.

RegularExpressionRestrictionDescription.description: Restricts to match a regular expression

SidebarBlockDescription.description:
Describes how the available types should be represented in the sidebar.
It is perfectly fine to have multiple sidebar descriptions for the
same underlying type.

defaultNode.description:
This description will be instanciated every time an "empty" node
is needed. This happens e.g. when the user starts dragging this
block from the sidebar.

displayName.description: The name to be displayed in the sidebar

TreeBlockLanguageGeneratorDescription.description:
Visualizes a block language by showing the tree structure. This is not
very user friendly but probably useful to debug.

TruckWorldEditorMenuComponentDescription.description: The world settings and tile selector for truck worlds

TypeReference.description:
Simple strings are used to refer to local types that share the
same language name.

VisualBlockDescriptions.BlockStyle.description:
We currently allow any CSS style to be used.

TODO: This could be a Readonly__ type but that causes the JSON-
schema generator to (sort of rightfully) emit false for
"additionalProperties" and that in turn makes this type rather
pointless.

VisualBlockDescriptions.DropTargetProper.description: These properties are required to specify drop targets.

VisualBlockDescriptions.EditorBlock.description:
Describes how a certain block should be represented. Blocks are
always draggable and also possible drop targets.

VisualBlockDescriptions.EditorConstant.description: Displays a constant value that does not allow any user interaction.

VisualBlockDescriptions.EditorContainer.description: An element that exists merely for layout purposes, think "div" or "span"

VisualBlockDescriptions.EditorDropTarget.description:
Describes a "block" that only acts as a hole to drop things at.
It is not necesarily visible in every state and it is not draggable.

VisualBlockDescriptions.EditorErrorIndic.description: Shows a marker if there is some kind of error

VisualBlockDescriptions.EditorInput.description: Displays an interpolated value and allows it to be edited.

VisualBlockDescriptions.EditorInterpolat.description:
Displays a dynamic value that depends on some property of the node but
does not allow to edit the property.

VisualBlockDescriptions.EditorIterator.description: Allows to iterate over all blocks in a certain category.

VisualBlockDescriptions.VisibilityExpres.description: This expression is evaluated to determine whether a drop target should be shown.

VisualBlockDescriptions.VisibilityVars.description: These variables are available when evaluating drop target visibility.
